SP.P: Claimst thou preheminence, com down proud boy

SP.SPEAKER: vig.
SP.L: Then lets try maistries, and one conquer all,
We climd at once, and we at once will fall.

SP.SPEAKER: peri.
SP.P: They that loue Peridure deuide themselues vppon their part.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.P: That am I.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: and I.

SP.SPEAKER: vig.
SP.P: They that loue vs on this side.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: And I.

SP.SPEAKER: vig.
SP.P: Then to the field, to set our sister free.

SP.SPEAKER: perid.
SP.P: By all my hopes with her ile captiue thee.

SP.SPEAKER: vig.
SP.P: Trumpets and Drums, triumphant musick sing.

SP.SPEAKER: perid.
SP.P: this day a captiue, or a compleat king.

SP.SPEAKER: Somb.
SP.L: Sir you haue sworne to manage these affaires,
Euen with your best of iudgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Sicoph.
SP.L: I haue prouided, you will let me share,
Of the Grand-benefit you get by dice,
Deceitfull Cards, and other cozening games
you bring into the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: C.
SP.L: O rare, now shall I find out crab, som notable knauery

SP.SPEAKER: Somb.
SP.L: You shall haue equall share with Somebody,
Prouided, you will help to apprehend that Nobody,
On whom the guilt shall lye,
Of all those cheting tricks I haue deuisd.

SP.SPEAKER: C.
SP.L: O the fates, treason against my m. person, but I beleeue
Somb. wil pay fort, ile tickle your long wast for this ifaith,

SP.SPEAKER: Sico.
SP.P: Giue me some bales of dice. What are these?

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: Those are called high Fulloms.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Ile Fullom you for this.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: Those low Fulloms▪

SP.SPEAKER: C.
SP.P: They may chance bring you as hie as the Gallowes.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: Those Demi-bars.

SP.SPEAKER: clow.
SP.P: Great reason you shovld come to the barre before the gallows.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: Those bar Sizeaces.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: A couple of Asses indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: Those Brisle dice.

SP.SPEAKER: clo.
SP.P: Tis like they brisle, for I am sure theile breed anger

SP.SPEAKER: sicop.
SP.L: Now sir, as you haue compast all the Dice,
So I for cards. These for the game at maw,
All saving one, are Cut next vnder that,
Lay me the Ace of Harts, then cut the Cards,
O your fellow must needs haue it in his first tricke.

SP.SPEAKER: clow.
SP.P: Ile teach you a trick for this yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: sicop.
SP.L: these for Premero cut vpon the sides,
As thr other on the ends.

SP.SPEAKER: clow.
SP.P: Marke the end of all this.

SP.SPEAKER: sicop.
SP.L: these are for post and paire, these for saunt,
these for new cut.

SP.SPEAKER: clown.
SP.P: theile make you cut a fether one day,

SP.SPEAKER: sico.
SP.L: Well, these disperst, and No-body
Attacht for all these crimes, shalbe hangd.

SP.SPEAKER: clow.
SP.P: I or els you shall hange for him,

SP.SPEAKER: sico.
SP.P: Come, shals about our busines.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: Content, lets straight about it.

SP.SPEAKER: clow.
SP.P:
O my hart, that it was my fortune to heare all thys,
but beware a lucky man whllst you liue, Alasse if I had not rescued my maister, the swaggering fellowe woulde haue made No-body of him. Againe if I had not ouerheard this treason to his person, these Cunnicatching knaues, woulde haue made lesse then Nobody of him. For indeed they wold haue hangd him, but heeres my maister, O sweet maister how cheere you?

SP.SPEAKER: Nobo.
SP.P: O excellent, admirable, and beyond comparison, I thinke my shape inchants them.

SP.SPEAKER: clo.
SP.P: I think not so, for if I wer a Lady, I should neuer abide you: but Maister, I can tell you rare newes you must be ap∣prehended, for a Cheater, a Cozener, a Libiller, and I know not what.

SP.SPEAKER: Nobo.
SP.P: Not I, I am an innocent, no Cheater, no Cozener, but a simple honest man, hunted from place to place by some-body.

SP.SPEAKER: clo.
SP.L: tis true sir, it is one som. that would attach you, therfore
Looke to your selfe, but Mai. if you be tooke neuer feare,
I heard all their knauery, and I can cleare you I warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: O haue I found you, this is he my frends,
We haue long sought, you know when twas inquird,
Who brought the false Dice, and the cheating cards
Into the court, twas answered No-body.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo. No.
SP.P: (qd tha) I am affraid youle proue the knaue som.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: Lay hold vpon him, beare him to the prison.

SP.SPEAKER: No.
SP.P: To prison, say you well, if I be guilty this fellow is my partner take him to.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: Are you confederate in this treason sirra?

SP.SPEAKER: clo.
SP.L: If I be not sir some-body is, but if I be guilty I must beare
If off with head and shoulders.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.L: To prison with them, now the bird is caught,
For whom so long, through Britane haue I sought.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: I beleeue I haue a bird in a box, shal catcht you for all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Someb.
SP.P: Away with them I say.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter seuerally Peridure, Vigenius, Cornewell, Martianus, Morgan, Malgo, with drum and Coulors.

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.P: In Armes well met, ambitious Peridure,

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.L: Vigenius thou salutes me with a title,
Most proper to thy selfe,

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.P: Art thou not proud.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.L: Onely to meet thee on this bed of death,
Wherein the Title to the English Crowne,
Shall perish with thy selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.L: Faire is the end
Of such as die in honourable warre,
Oh far more faire, then on a bed of downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Warre is the souldiors haruest it cuts downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.P: The liues of such as hinder our renowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.P: Such as are apt for tumult.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.L: Such as you,
That to our lawfull Soueraigne are vntrue.

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.P: Blushes not Peridure to braue vs so.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.L: Blushes Vigenius at thy ouerthrow,
Who wast that told me he would submit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sicoph.
SP.P: Twas I my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.L: Peace foole thou doest forget,
Tis not an hower since, to our princely eare,
Thou saidst thou did desire vs to forbeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Sicoph.
SP.P: True my good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.P: True that I sought to stay.

SP.SPEAKER: vig.
SP.P: That I would basely my ritcht hopes betray.

SP.SPEAKER: Sico.
SP.P: I did it of mine owne head to make you friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.P: Still playing of the Sicophant.

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.P: What still.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.P: A glose I see to insinuate our good will.

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.P: That whosoeuer conquerd, he might gaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.P: the fauour of vs both, that was his trayne.

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.P: But henceforth we cashiere thee from the filde.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid
SP.L: Neuer heereafter beare a souldiers shield,
A souldiers sword, nor any other grace,
But what is like thine owne, a doubble face.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.P: Now I beseech Ioue heare my praier, let them bee both slaine in the battell.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.L: If there be any other of his hart,
We giue them free licence to depart.

SP.SPEAKER: corn.
SP.P: Cornwell hates flattery.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: So does Martianus.

SP.SPEAKER: Malg.
SP.P: Malgo is resolute for all affaires.

SP.SPEAKER: Morg.
SP.P: And so is Morgan, for he scornes delayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.L: then where the fielde consists of such a spirit,
He that subdues conquers the Crowne by merit.

SP.SPEAKER: perid.
SP.P: thats I.

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.P: tis I.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.P: Ryuers in blood declare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Vig.
SP.P: Grasse turne to Crimson if vigenius spare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Elid.
SP.P: Aire be made purple with our reaking gore.

SP.SPEAKER: vige.
SP.P: Follow my frends.

SP.SPEAKER: Perid.
SP.P: Conquer or neare giue ore.

DIV1.STAGE: Alarum, Excursious, periduras, and vigenius fight, and both slaine.
Enter cornwell, Martianus, Morgan, and Malgo.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: this way I saw vigenius on the spur.

SP.SPEAKER: corn.
SP.P: I periduras, this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Morg.
SP.P: A strang fight, my Lord is breathlesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Malg.
SP.P: My deare Lord is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: True Brothers in ambition, and in death.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: Yet we are enemies, why fight we not
With one another, for our generals losse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: To much blood already hath beene spent,
Now therefore since the difference in themselues,
Is reconsiled in eithers ouerthrow,
Let vs be as we were before this Iar,
And ioyning hands like honorable frends,
Inter their bodyes as becomes their state,
And which is rare once more to Elidure,
Who now in prison leades a wearied life,
With true submission offer Englands Crowne.
Of all the charges of tumultuous fate,
This is most strange three times to flow in state.

SP.SPEAKER: Queene.
SP.L: You are welcome, what new flatteries,
Are a coyning in the mint of that smoth face?

SP.SPEAKER: Sicoph.
SP.P: Where is the Lady Elidor I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Amongst my other waiting maides at worke.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.L: Tis well, yet Madam with your gratious leaue
I wish it better.

SP.SPEAKER: Queene.
SP.L: What in loue with her,
Canst thou affect such a deiected wretch,
Then I perceiue thy flattery is folly,
Or thout proue honest, louing one so poore.

SP.SPEAKER: Sico.
SP.L: I know not Madam what your highnesse gathers
Out of my troubled words, I loue you well,
And though the time should alter, as I am sure,
It is impossible, yet I would follow
All your misfortunes with a patient hart.

SP.SPEAKER: Queene.
SP.P: I haue seene too much of thee to credit thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sico.
SP.L: Now in your height of glory vse your seruant,
now Madam, whilst the noble Peridure
That loues you dearer then the Brittish Crowne,
Whilst hees conqueror, vse me to destroy
Your greatest enemy, and I will doe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Queene.
SP.P: Thou wilt not.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.L: Be it Elidure the king,
The prisoner I should say, Ide murder him,
To shew how much I loue your maiesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.L: Thou wouldst not poyson for me his base Queene,
Whom I so often haue triumphed ore,
That torment now is her beatitude,
And tedious vnto me.

SP.SPEAKER: sico.
SP.P: no more, shes dead.

SP.SPEAKER: queene.
SP.L: See where she comes, dispatch her presently,
For though the Princely Peridure be king,
His brothers death in time will make him odious
Vnto his subiects, and they may restore
Mild Elidure againe, and then I dye,

SP.SPEAKER: sico.
SP.P: Withdraw, shes dead, as surely as you liue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: What shall I neuer from this seruitude
Receiue releasant euermore be plagud,
With this insulting Queen? Is there no change,
no other alteration in the state
I know there is not, I am borne to be
a slaue, to one baser then slauery

SP.SPEAKER: sioo.
SP.P: I will release you by a speedy death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: By death, alasse, what tongue pronounst that word?
What my Lord weather-cocke? nay then I see,
Death in thy mouth is but base flattery.

SP.SPEAKER: sico.
SP.P: By heauen I am sent to kill you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: By whose meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: sico.
SP.P: By one that will auouch it when tis done.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: not the proud queene.

SP.SPEAKER: sico.
SP.L: Yes, but I am determined
in full amends for all my flattery,
to saue your life, and kill her instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Oh if a Divell would vndertake that deed,
I card not though she heard me, I would say,
He were a starre more glorious then the day.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.P: And would you for that good deed pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And quite all former iniury.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.L: But let me tell your highnes by the way,
the Queene is not so hasty of your death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: no, for she had rather haue my life prolongd.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.L: I do assure your highnes on mine honor,
When I did say she sent me to destroy you,
I slaunderd her great mercy towards you,
For she had giuen me order to release you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady
SP.P: Oh monstrous lie.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.L: beleeue it, for tis true:
And this moreouer, she somuch repents
Her former pride and hardnes towards you,
that she could wish it neuer had bin done.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: then I repent me of my wrongs towards her,
And in the stead of a reward proposd
to him that should destroy her, I do wish,
Death be his death, that vndertakes the deed.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.L: but will you not forget these princelie words,
if any alteration should ensue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: not I, I in my oths am true.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.P: Except once more the Lords crowne Elydure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: though that should chance, ile hold my promise sure.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.P: And you too Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: So thou muderst hir.

SP.SPEAKER: sico.
SP.L: Know that Lord periduras and his
brother, are in the battell slaine, and by the nobles,
her husband Elidure raisd to the state,
setting aside all iesting, Queene beleeue it.
And truce with her, least she triumph againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Queen.
SP.P: For Gods sake make vs friends.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.P: Good Lord how strange this reconciled foes be∣hold each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Queen.
SP.P: Kind sister.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.P: Then make me your brother, say are you friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: We are.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.L: Then chance what can,
in this I haue prooud my selfe an honest man.

SP.SPEAKER: Malgo.
SP.L: The king your husband, madam new releast,
Desires your presence at his Coronation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My Elydure a third time to be crownd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mal.
SP.P: True Madam, and expects your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And you knew this before.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.P: No on mine honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Neither you Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Queene.
SP.P: neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: If you did My oath is past, and what I haue lately sworne ile hold inui∣olate, here all stryfe ends, thy wit has made two proude shrewes perfect friends.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter in state, Elidure, Cornwell, Martianus, Morgan, and all the Lords.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: A third time liue our gratious soueraigne
Monarch of England, crowned by these hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Elid.
SP.L: A third time Lords, I do returne your loue,
And wish it with my soule, so heauen were pleasd,
My ambitious Brothers had not died for this,
But we haue giuen them honorable graues.
And mournd their most vntimely funerall,
My loued Queen, come seat thee by my side,
Partner in all my sorrowes and my ioyes,
And you her reconciled Sister sit,
By her in second place of maiesty,
It ioyes me that you haue outworne your pride.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Methinks my gratious husband and my King,
I neuer tooke more pleasure in my glasse,
Then I receiue in her society.

SP.SPEAKER: Queen.
SP.P: Nor I in all my state as in her loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Elid.
SP.L: My Lord of Cornwell, whose that whispers to you?
Or whats the newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: My liege, he tels me heeres a great contention
betwixt two noted persons of the Land
much spoke of by all states, one some-body
Hath brought before your highnes and this presence,
An infamous and strange opiniond fellow,
Cald No-body, they would intreat your highnes,
To heare their matters scand.

SP.SPEAKER: Elid.
SP.L: Weele sit in person on their controuersies,
Admit them Cornwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Is that strange monster tooke, somuch renownd,
In Citty, Court, and Country, for lewd prancks.
Tis well, weel heare how he can purge himselfe.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter some-body, bringing in No-body and his man, with Billes and staues.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: now sirrha we haue brought you before the king,
Wheres your hart now?

SP.SPEAKER: Nob.
SP.P: My harts in my hose, but my face was neuer asha∣med to shew it selfe, yet before king or Keyser.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: And wheres your hart sirrha?

SP.SPEAKER: Clowne.
SP.P: My harts lower then my hofe, for mine it at my heel, but whersoeuer it is, it is a true hart, and so is not somb.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.L: Health to your Maiestie, and to the Queene,
With a hart lower then this humble earth
whereon I kneele. I beg against this fellow,
Iustice my liege.

SP.SPEAKER: Eli.
SP.P: Against whom.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: Against No-body.

SP.SPEAKER: No.
SP.L: My liege, his words wel sute vnto his thoughts,
He wishes no man Iustice, being composd
Of all deceit, of subtilty and slight,
For mine own part, if in this royall presence,
And before all these true iudiciall Lords,
I cannot with sincerenes cleare my selfe,
Of all suggestions falsly coynd against me,
Let me be hangd vp sunning in the ayre,
And made a scar-crow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Lets heare his accusations,
And then how well thou canst aquit thy selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.L: First, when this monster made his residence
Within the country, and disperst his shape
Through euery shire and country of the Land,
Where plenty had before a quiet seat,
And the poore commons of the Land were full,
With rich abundance and saciety,
At his ariue, great dearths and scarsity,
By ingrosing come, and racking poore mens rents.
This makes so many poore and honest Farmers,
to sell their leases, and to beg their bread,
this makes so many beggers in the Land.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: I but what proofe or lawfull euidence
Can you bring forth, that this was done by him.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.L: My Lord I tras't him, and so found him out,
But should your Lordship not beleeue my proofe,
Examine all the rich and wealthy chuffes,
Whose full cramd Garners to the roofes are fild,
In euery dearth who makes this scarsitye,
And euery man will clearely quit himselfe,
Then consequently, it must be No-body.
Base copper money is stampt, the mint disgrast,
Make search who doth this, euery man cleares one,
So consequently it must be No-body.
Besides, whereas the nobles of the land,
And Gentlemen built goodly manner houses,
Fit to receiue a King, and all his traine,
And there kept royall hospitality,
Since this intestine monster No-body,
Dwels in these goodly houses keepes no traine,
A hundred Chimnies, and not one cast smoke,
And now the cause of these, mock-begger Hal,
Is this they, are dwelt in by No-body,
For this out of the countrey he was chast.

SP.SPEAKER: No.
SP.L: My royall liedge whie am I thus disgrast,
Ile proue that slandrous wretch hath this al done.

SP.SPEAKER: Elid.
SP.L: Tis good you can acquit you, such abuses,
Growe in the countrey, and vnknowne to vs:
nay then no maruell that so manie poore,
starue in the streets and beg from doore, to doore.
Then sirha purge you from this countrey blame,
Or we will make thee the worlds publike shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.P: now No-body, vvhat can you say to this.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: My M. hath good cards, on his side Ile vvarant him.

SP.SPEAKER: No.
SP.L: my Lord, you knovv that slanders are no proofes,
nor vvords without their present euidence,
If things were done, they must be done by some-body,
Else could they haue no being. Is corne hoorded,
some-body hords it, else it would be delt,
In mutuall plentie throughout all the land,
Are their rents raisd, if No-body should doe it,
then should it be vndone. Is
Base money stampt, and the kings letters forgd,
Some-body needes must doe it, therefore not I,
And where he saies, great houses long since built,
Lye destitute, and wast because inhabited,
By No-body my liedge, I answer thus,
If Some-body dwelt therein, I would giue place.
Or wold he but alow those chimnies fire,
They would cast cloudes to heauen, the Kitchin-foode
It would releeue the poore, the sellers beere,
It would make strangers dinke, but he commits
These outragies then laies the blame on me,
And for my good deed, I am made a scorne.
I onely giue the tired a refuge seat,
The vnclothd garments, and the starued meate.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.L: How say you by this maister Some-body. I beleeue
you will be found out by and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: If this be true my liedge, as true it is,
Some-body will be found an arrant cheater,
Vnlesse he better can acquit himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sich.
SP.P: Touch him with the citty, since you haue taken the foile in the Countrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sirha, what can you say to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Someb.
SP.L: What should I saie my Lord, see heare complaints,
Made in the citty against no-body,
Aswell as in the country. See their bils,
Heeres one complaines his wife hath bin abroad,
And asking where she reuels night, by night,
She answers she hath bin with no-body.
Heares queanes maintaind in euery suburb streete,
Aske who maintaines them, and tis no-body.
Watches are, beaten, and Constables are scoft,
In dead of night men are made drunke in tauernes,
Girles loose their maiden heads at thirteene yeares,
Pockets pickt, and purses cut in throngs.

SP.SPEAKER: Queene.
SP.L: Inough, inough, doth no-body all this?
Though he hath cleard himselfe from country crimes,
He cannot scape the citty.

SP.SPEAKER: No.
SP.L: Yes dread Queene,
I must confesse these things are daily done,
For which I heere accuse this Some-body,
That euery where with slaunders dogs my steps,
And cunningly assumes my borrowed shape,
Women lie out, if they be tooke and found
with somebody, then No-body goes cleere,
Else the blames mine, he doth these faults vnknowne,
then slanders my chast innocence for proofe.
somebody doth maintaine a common strumpet
ith Garden-allies, and vndid himselfe.
somebody swaggered with the watch last night,
was carried to the counter.
somebody once pickt a pocket in this Play-house yard,
Was hoysted on the stage, and shamd about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Ha, ha, hath my maister met with you.

SP.SPEAKER: no.
SP.L: Alasse my liege, your honest No-bodie
Builds Churches in these dayes, and Hospitals,
Releeues the seuerall prisons in the Citty,
Redeemes the needy debtor from the hole,
And when this somebody brings infant children,
And leaues them in the night at strangers doores,
Nobody fathers them, prouides them nurses,
What should I say, your highnes loue I craue,
That am all iust.

SP.SPEAKER: corn.
SP.P: Then somebodies a knaue.

SP.SPEAKER: sicoph.
SP.P: If neyther citty nor countrie wil preuaile to him, with the court ma. somebody, and there you will match him.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: Then touching his abuses in the court.

SP.SPEAKER: corn.
SP.L: I marrie Nobody what say you to this,
See, heere are dangerous Libils gainst the state,
And no name to them, therefore nobodies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Besides strange rumors and false buzzing tales,
Of mutinous leesings raisd by No-body.

SP.SPEAKER: Malg.
SP.P: False dice and Cheating brought euen to the pre∣sence, and who dares be so impudently knauish,
Vnlesse some fellow of your name and garbe.

SP.SPEAKER: Morg.
SP.L: Cards of aduantage with such cheating tricks,
Brought euen amongst the noblest of the land,
And when these cosening shifts are once discouered,
There is no cheater found saue No-body.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: How canst thou answer these.

SP.SPEAKER: nobo.
SP.L: Euen as the rest,
Are libels cast, if nobody did make them,
And no-bodies name to them, they are no libels,
For he that sets his name to any slander,
Makes it by that no libell, this aproues
He forgd those slanderous writs to scandall me.
And for false cards, and dice, let my great slops
And his big bellied dublet both be sercht,
And see which harbors most hipocrisie.

SP.SPEAKER: queene.
SP.P: Let them both be sercht.

SP.SPEAKER: sico.
SP.P: Ile take my leaue of the presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: nay M. sicophant weele haue the inside of your poc∣kets translated to, weele see what stuffyng they haue, Ile take a little paines with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Elid.
SP.P: What haue you there in nobodyes pockets.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: Here are my liedge bonds forfei by poore men,
Which he releast out of the vsurers hands,
And canceld. Leases likewise forfeited,
By him repurchast. These peticions,
Of many poore men to preferre their sutes.
Vnto your highnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Elid.
SP.L: Thou arte Iust we know,
All great mens pockets should be lined so.

SP.P: What bumbast beares his gorge.

SP.L: False Cards, false Dice;
The kings hand counterfeit,
Bonds put in sute to gaine the forfitures,
forgd deedes to cheate men of their ancient land,
And thousand such like trashe.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Nay looke you heere, heares one that for his bones is pretily stuft. Heares fulloms and gourds: heeres tall-men & low-men Heere tray duce ace, passedge comes a pace.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.P: Mercy great King.

SP.SPEAKER: Sicoph.
SP.P: Mercy my Soueraigne.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: My liedge you cannot to be seuere in punishing,
Those monstrous crimes, the onely staine and blemish
To the weale-publike.

SP.SPEAKER: Eli.
SP.L: Villaines heare your doome,
Thou that hast bin the oppressyon of the poore,
Shalt bee more poore then penury it slfe,
All that thou hast is forfit to the Law,
For thy extortion I will haue thee branded,
Vpon the forhead with the letter F.
For Cheating whipt, for forging loose thine eares,
Last for a basing of thy Soueraignes Coyne,
And traitrous impresse of our kingly seale,
Suffer the death of traitors. Beare him hence.

SP.SPEAKER: som.
SP.L: Since I must needs be martird graunt me this,
That No-body may whip, or torture me,
Or hang me for a traitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Morg
SP.P: Away with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Or if needs I must dye a traitors death,
That No-body may see me when I dye.

SP.SPEAKER: Malg.
SP.P: Hence with the traitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: I know by your complexion you wer ripe for the hang∣mn, but now to this leane Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.L: Let me doome him, smoth spaniel, soothing grome
Slicke Oyly knaue, egregious parasite,
Thou turning vane, and changing Weather-cocke,
My sentence is thou shalt be naked stript,
And by the citty beadles soundly whipt.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Ile make bold to see thexecution.

SP.SPEAKER: No.
SP.P: Well hath the King decreed, now by your highnesse patience let No-body borrow a word or two of Euery-bo∣dy.

DIV1.HEAD: The Epilogue.
DIV1.P: Heer if you wonder why the king Elidurus bestowes no∣thing on me for all my good seruices in his land, if the multitude shuld say he hath preferd No-body, Some-body or other would say it were not well done, for in doing good to No-body he should but get himselfe an il name. There∣fore I will leaue my sute to him, and turne to you. Kinde Gentleman if any-body heere dislike No-body, then I hope Euery-body haue pleased you, for being offended with no-body, nor Any-body can finde himselfe agrieued, Gentle∣men they haue a cold sute that haue no-body to speak in their cause, and therefore blame vs not to feare, yet our comfort is this, if no-body haue offended you cannot blame No-bo∣dy for it, or rather we will finde Some-body heareafter shall make good the fault that no-body hath done, and so I craue the generall grace of Euery-body.

SP.SPEAKER: Eli.
SP.L: now forward Lords, long may our glories stand,
Three sundry times Crownd king of this faire land.
